choices.D: An implicit deny is causing R1 to block network traffic.
choices.C: A deny all ACL entry is currently active on R1.
choices.A: The permit all ACL entry on R1 is inactive.
choices.B: The ACL of R1 is misconfigured.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. While you troubleshoot a connectivity issue to a PC behind R1, you enter the show access-lists command to generate this output. Which reason for the problem is most likely true?

discussion.content:
D is correct
and C is confusing but don't confuse yourself the C state that "all ACL" it's not true because the cmd only deny "TCP"

questions.question_text: How can you disable DTP on a switch port?

discussion.content: The correct answer is D. Change the administrative mode to access.

comments.content:
The Answer is D. Look at your output. 

**Administrative Mode: static access**

discussion.content:
Correct answer is C

Output of show interfaces gi0/21 switchport

Name: Gi0/21
Switchport: Enabled
Administrative Mode: static access
Operational Mode: down
Administrative Trunking Encapsulation: dot1q
Negotiation of Trunking: Off
Access Mode VLAN: 1 (default)

The only way to disable DTP on a switch port is to use the “switchport nonegotiate” command. notice this command can only be used after configuring that switch port in “trunk” or “access” mode.
Therefore this is a question with no correct answer. will choose answer A. At least it is correct in theory but D is also good Answer. I will go for A.

choices.B: Add an interface on the switch to a channel group.
choices.A: Configure the switch port as a trunk.
choices.C: Change the operational mode to static access.
choices.D: Change the administrative mode to access.

choices.B: The tunnel destination address is incorrect.
choices.C: The route between the networks is undefined.
choices.A: The tunnel source address is incorrect.

questions.question_text: After you configure a GRE tunnel between two networks, the tunnel comes up normally, but workstations on each side of the tunnel cannot communicate. Which reason for the problem is most likely true?

discussion.content:
The question leaves a lot for interpretation but I do think that it should be D. The question says 'the tunnel comes up normally, but the workstations [...] cannot communicate'. This implies that tunnels are used more often and a default route should be defined. When the route is undefined, the whole tunnel goes down. And in this case, the question suggests that the tunnel doesn't go down completely but that there is no connectivity. So it should be a MTU issue. See also:

https://community.cisco.com/t5/routing/gre-issue-tunnel-up-down-on-one-side-and-up-up-on-the-other-side/td-p/2414642

D is wrong 
C is correct 
after GRE establishment complete R1 and R2 work like LAN and need a route to reach the other side of the subnet.
I think C is the right answer. default route has to be defined
I think "D" is likely wrong. I believe C. The route between the networks is undefined is more likely to be the correct answer.

choices.A: The router will forward the packet via either Serial0 or Serial1.
choices.C: The router will forward the packet via Serial2.
choices.D: The router will drop the packet.
choices.B: The router will return the packet to its source.

discussion.content:
No (correct me if I am wrong), as PauloPinho said, there is no route in the routing table that would match that IP address. Routers select a route that exists, and sends it to the route with the longest prefix. 

However, in this case there isn't one, and so that's where the gateway of last resort comes in to play.

Would the Anwser not be A, due to the rule of specificity? that the the 192.0.2.0/24 would be the closest destination learned by EIGRP and as the router has 2 equal routes, would it not attempt to load balance?

comments.content: No, in that route table have a gateway of last resort, and, if the address or network dont do a match in the route table, the router will send the packet to gateway.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. How will the router handle a packet destined for 192.0.2.156?

Instructions -
- Enter Cisco IOS commands on device to verify network operation and answer for multiple-choice questions.
- THIS TASK DOES NOT REQUIRE DEVICE CONFIGURATION.
- Click the device icon to gain access to the console of the router. No console or enable passwords are required.
- To access the multiple-choice questions, click the numbered boxes on the left of the top panel.
- This task has four multiple-choice questions. Be sure to answer all four questions before clicking the Next button.

Scenario -
You are implementing PPP over serial links between R1 router and branch offices. In Phase 1 you must implement and verify PPP and GRE tunnel configurations as mentioned in the topology. In Phase 2 your colleague is expected to do NAT and ISP configurations between R1 and ISP router.
Identify the issues that you encounter during PPP over serial links implementation.
Routers Branch1, Branch2, and Branch3 connect to Router R1 in the main office over serial links.
PPP multilink implementation is recommended between R1 and Branch1 routers.
The GRE tunnel is configured between R2 and Branch2 routers, and traffic between Server farm1 10.10.10.0/24 network and Branch2 LAN 10.10.20.0/24 network, is routed over GRE tunnel using static route.
You have console access on R1, R2, Branch1, Branch2, and Branch3 devices. Use only show commands to troubleshoot the issues.
//IMG//

Why did Branch1 router lose WAN connectivity with R1 router?

choices.B: The PPP multilink group is misconfigured on the Branch1 serial interfaces.
choices.A: The IP address is misconfigured on PPP multilink interface on the Branch1 router.
choices.D: The Branch1 serial interfaces are placed in a shutdown condition.
choices.C: The PPP multilink group in misconfigured on the R1 serial interfaces.

questions.answer_description:
First we should check both routers with the "show ip interface brief" command. On R1:

On Branch1:

We can see that although the Multilink1 interfaces are in "up/up" state but they are not in the same subnet. According to the IP address scheme shown on the topology we can deduce the Multilink interface on Branch1 has been misconfigured, it should be 192.168.14.2 instead.

discussion.content: A wrong configuration is added. Must be the interface configuration on branch-1, not the branch-2
